content.question: Which of the following best explains how income taxes can moderate a business cycle during an expansion?

choices.label: Tax revenues increase automatically as gross domestic product <math alttext="open parenthesis, G D P, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>(GDP)</mtext></mrow></math> rises, which dampens consumption spending.
Tax revenues decrease automatically as <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></math> rises, which increases short-run aggregate supply.
Tax revenues increase automatically as <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></math> falls, which decreases short-run aggregate supply.
Tax revenues increase automatically as <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></math> falls, which prevents the economy from experiencing a downturn.
Tax revenues decrease automatically as <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></math> falls, which dampens consumption spending.

content.answer: Tax revenues increase automatically as gross domestic product <math alttext="open parenthesis, G D P, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>(GDP)</mtext></mrow></math> rises, which dampens consumption spending.
